ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course makes you look granularly at your writing. Everything you think you know about writing is put to the wayside and you start looking at the craft in a whole new light.
I learned so much about what good writing looks like!

Taking Verlyn's class will make you a better writer. There's no other class at Yale that can make you as in tune with your voice and improve your writing as quickly and substantially as Verlyn's Genre of the Sentence. The weekly readings are short but selected specifically to address the needs of the people in the class.

At the start of this class, Klinkenborg said it would totally transform the way we wrote, and the way we viewed writing. What a statement to deliver on! This course gave me a ton of insight into the minutiae of writing at the sentence level. It also changed my perspective on the relationship between writing and thought, the function and value of writing in my life, and a whole lot else.

I learned how to write clear / sharp / short sentences, how to critically assess other essayists' writing, and, most importantly, how to edit my own prose. Verlyn and Emily did an amazing job at providing clear, comprehensive feedback on my essays. With their feedback, I've developed greater self-awareness in my writing. When are my metaphors unnecessary? When will a short sentence be clearer than a prolonged one? How can I direct the reader's attention with a carefully placed colon? With their feedback, I've developed a fuller understanding of my writing strengths / flaws, and where I have room for improvement!
I learned how to write more clearly and creatively. I can't really synthesize everything I learned in the box allotted. Truly, this is an important class for any aspiring writer.

In this course I learned to write well on every level. My attention to sentences and rhythm improved most, I think, but Im also leaving the class with a new outlook on the purpose of good writing and what its role can be in my life. The process of noticing my thoughts has also taught me a great deal about what it means to be me and to see the world through my eyes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There aren't many weaknesses. The strengths are that the course is engaging, just the right amount of work, and you learn so much about writing in such a little amount of time.
I dont have many reccomendations for improvement on this course. The consistency of the syllabus and classes was a huge strength.

Writing a unique piece every week was, at first, a little daunting. By the end, though, writing the pieces felt like a giftand it never really feels like work. 
Verlyn (and Emily!) is the strength of this course. Verlyn line-edits your work and writes you a few sentences about what you've turned in every week. Let me say that againhe edits and comments on EVERY student's prose, two pages per student, every week. I've never had a professor so committed to his studentsand I don't think I ever will again. I've had professors never hand my papers back to me!! This is not this course. Verlyn is also incredibly dedicated to your well-being: he will tell you and your classmates that he really does care about how you're doing. And he means it. Also, your class might get to visit Verlyn's farm at the end of the semester! Verlyn is truly the best! Simply no weaknesses.

Verlyn and Emily are the most thoughtful, kind, and wise professors and make the class what it is. I loved every minute of this class and have never thought so carefully both about the world around me and where I fit in within it.

Klinkenborg is wonderful, and fosters a really welcoming and open class environment. The uniform weekly two-pagers gave the class a consistency that I liked without ever becoming too much of a burden. Most thorough, clear feedback I've ever gotten in a writing class. No weaknesses come to mind.

Strengths: Verlyn and Emily give excellent feedback -- line-by-line edits, but also broader structural critiques. Class engagement is enriching: people give deep attention to every piece (student or assigned) that we read. And the pace and structure -- one, two-page, essay a week -- is manageable and allowed me to improve and experiment with my writing incrementally. 

Weaknesses: Only one -- I wish we'd been more critical of some assigned pieces. It felt like every assigned weekly reading was a work to be celebrated (rightfully so, most of them were amazing), but there wasn't much class discussion on where these writers may have faltered. Maybe leaving more time to answer questions like "Anything we didn't like about this piece?" would help.
No weaknesses. The course was engaging and educational. I was challenged in new ways that have forever changed my writing.

The rhythm of this course was perfect. Verlyns weekly feedback was outstanding and his words of wisdom in class and offices hours always made me feel better about life. I loved reading my classmates pieces each week. I learned a lot from them and from the assigned reading. No weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is the best class I've taken at Yale. If you get into this class, take it. ENGL 474 is really one of the formative classes you can take if you want to be a writer. You will never look at writing the same.
YES YES yes! Prof. Klinkenborg is one of the best professors Ive had. He really takes the time to get to know each student and their writing individually, which is really meaningful.
YES!! This is the best class at Yale. I don't think another class will ever come close to this one.
Absolutely  this is a transformative creative writing class.
I recommend this course to every Yale student. It's far and away the best course I've taken at Yale. Run, don't walk.

Yes yes yes yes! Verlyn will give every piece you write his full attention. His, and Emily's, feedback is invaluable. You may not agree with every suggestion, but you'll walk away with a greater self-awareness as a writer.
Most definitely. This class changes the way you write and read in the best way. Fundamental for any aspiring writer.
Absolutely. I would take this course every semester of college if I could. I often ignored work for other classes because I only wanted to be writing my weekly piece for this class.

extras.title: ENGL 474 02 - The Genre of the Sentence
